title: Michel Hidalgo
text:
Michel François Hidalgo (22 March 1933 – 26 March 2020) was a French professional <a href="football%20player">footballer</a> and <a href="Manager%20%28association%20football%29">manager</a>. He was the head coach of the <a href="France%20national%20football%20team">French national team</a> from 1976 to 1984, with whom he won the <a href="UEFA%20Euro%201984">UEFA Euro 1984</a> on home soil, also reaching the semi-finals of the <a href="1982%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1982 FIFA World Cup</a>.
Early life.
Michel François Hidalgo was born 22 March 1933 in <a href="Leffrinckoucke">Leffrinckoucke</a>, Nord. He was born to a Spanish-born father and a French mother in northern France, and grew up in <a href="Normandy">Normandy</a>, where he started playing <a href="association%20football">football</a>. He was named after Mexican patriot <a href="Miguel%20Hidalgo%20y%20Costilla">Miguel Hidalgo y Costilla</a>.
Club career.
A <a href="midfielder">midfielder</a>, Hidalgo was champion of Normandie Juniors in 1952 with "US Normande", before signing up tp <a href="Le%20Havre%20AC">Le Havre's</a> books for two seasons, later playing for <a href="Stade%20de%20Reims">Reims</a>, with whom he played and scored a goal in the 4–3 defeat to <a href="Real%20Madrid%20CF">Real Madrid</a> in the <a href="1956%20European%20Cup%20Final">1956 European Cup Final</a>, also winning a <a href="Ligue%201">league title</a> in 1955.
Under the wing of Rocher, who signed him for <a href="AS%20Monaco%20FC">Monaco</a>, Hidalgo won two league titles and two <a href="Coupe%20de%20France">national cup</a> titles with Monaco. Between 1964 and 1970, he presided over the UNFP, a players' <a href="syndicate">syndicate</a>.
International career.
At international level, Hidalgo was capped once for the <a href="France%20national%20football%20team">France national team</a> in 1962 in a friendly match against <a href="Italy%20national%20football%20team">Italy</a>.
Managerial career.
Hidalgo started managing the <a href="AS%20Monaco%20FC">Monaco</a> second team in 1967 and served as a player-manager with <a href="Rapid%20de%20Menton">Menton</a> from 1968 until 1969.
On 27 March 1976, he was appointed <a href="France%20national%20football%20team">France national team</a> head coach, replacing <a href="%C8%98tefan%20Kov%C3%A1cs">Ștefan Kovács</a> – under whom he had previously served as an assistant – during a time when France was having difficulty in major tournaments. Included in his side was <a href="playmaker">playmaker</a> and <a href="Captain%20%28association%20football%29">captain</a> <a href="Michel%20Platini">Michel Platini</a>, who helped the side turn a new page in their book and get back to winning ways. After suffering a first-round elimination at the <a href="1978%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1978 FIFA World Cup</a>, in the <a href="1982%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1982 FIFA World Cup</a> Hidalgo led the team to the semi-finals, where he lost to the <a href="Germany%20national%20football%20team">West German side</a> on penalties following a 3–3 draw after extra-time; France eventually finished the tournament in fourth place. In 1984, he won the <a href="UEFA%20Euro%201984">European Championship</a> on home soil, beating <a href="Spain%20national%20football%20team">Spain</a> 2–0 in the final in Paris; this was France's first major international title. The exciting attacking style of football that he implemented with the French national side during this period was known as "<a href="champagne">champagne</a> football" in the media. Hidalgo is also regarded as the architect of the French "carré magique" (magic square), which was nickname given to the creative and talented four-man midfield of the French national side during the 80s, which was made up of Michel Platini, <a href="Alain%20Giresse">Alain Giresse</a>, <a href="Jean%20Tigana">Jean Tigana</a>, and <a href="Luis%20Fernandez">Luis Fernandez</a>.
After his victory, he passed the reins over to his assistant <a href="Henri%20Michel">Henri Michel</a> and got a job as the National Technical Director, where he remained until 1986, afterwards choosing a managerial position at <a href="Olympique%20de%20Marseille">Marseille</a>. He is considered an idol among the <a href="Olympique%20de%20Marseille">Marseille</a> supporters. He strayed from the limelight after 1991, taking a sidelining role as a football pundit on "Demain, c'est foot", a football show on <a href="TMC%20Monte%20Carlo">TMC Monte Carlo</a>.
Death.
Hidalgo died on 26 March 2020 in <a href="Marseille">Marseille</a>, at the age of 87, after a lengthy struggle with a disease.
